scrape.translation[0].definitions[0].def: to remove something from a surface using the edge of a knife, a stick etc
scrape.translation[0].definitions[0].exa: Scrape the carrots and slice them thinly.
The two of them scraped their dishes clean.
The earth was scraped away to uncover a trapdoor.
Teresa scraped the mud off her boots.
scrape.translation[0].definitions[1].def: to rub against a rough surface in a way that causes slight damage or injury, or to make something do this
scrape.translation[0].definitions[1].exa: The coat was too long; the hem scraped the pavement.
I heard the side of the car scrape against the wall.
I scraped my knee painfully on the concrete.
scrape.translation[0].definitions[2].def: to make a noise by rubbing roughly against a surface
scrape.translation[0].definitions[2].exa: Chairs scraped loudly as they stood up.
He opened the gate quietly, trying not to let it scrape on the gravel.
scrape.translation[0].definitions[3].def: if a computer program scrapes data, it collects it from a website
scrape.translation[1].definitions[0].def: a mark or slight injury caused by rubbing against a rough surface
scrape.translation[1].definitions[0].exa: I came away from the accident with only cuts and scrapes.
scrape.translation[1].definitions[1].def: a situation in which you are in trouble or have difficulties
scrape.translation[1].definitions[1].exa: He got into all sorts of scrapes as a boy.
scrape.translation[1].definitions[2].def: the noise made when one surface rubs roughly against another
scrape.translation[1].definitions[2].exa: He heard the scrape of chairs being dragged across the floor.
